prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: band7-336
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Ortho-H2O line at band 7, 336.22762 GHz and Ortho-H2O line at band 7, 323.55402 GHz.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to map the 323 GHz and 336 GHz vibrationally excited H2O lines as well as related molecular lines (H2O and SiO masers) within the same observing bands with the highest spatial resolution with ALMA cycle 2. The technical justification is basically common for all of the Science Goals, except for line frequencies.
The target source is Orion KL radio Source I. The tracking center position is coincident with the peak position of the 336 GHz H2O line and continuum emissions observed in ALMA cycle 0. According to our cycle 0 observation of the 321 GHz H2O maser and vibrationally excited 336 GHz H2O line, the source size is estimated to be 100 AU in diameter corresponding to the angular size of about 0.2". Thus, we need the highest spatial resolution achieved in cycle 2, 0.13" at 323-336 GHz.
Observed lines are summarized in Table 1 in the Science Case pdf file and the spectral setting in OT. In addition to the primary target of the H2O lines at 323 GHz and 336 GHz, we include 321 GHz H2O maser and 336 GHz 30SiO (v=1) maser to reveal distributions of submillimeter H2O masers, SiO masers and lower excitation H2O molecular line (see the Science Case). The target H2O lines could be partially emitted as a result of maser action rather than thermal emission. In order to distinguish maser emission, we request relatively high frequency resolution of 282 kHz (~0.25 km s-1) with spectral averagin of 2, which is sufficiently finer than the typical line width of masers (~0.5 km s-1). On the other hand, we also image and self-calibrate the strong continuum emission of Source I by using line-free channels. Because there are number of spectral lines in the Orion KL region, we need high spectral resolution data from the FDM mode to identify the line-free channels in the continuum subtraction. For this purpose, we set these spectral windows named as "continuum and lines" in the OT with the resolution of 564 kHz (~0.5 km s-1) with spectral averaging of 2. To avoid band edges at 321GHz and strong atmospheric absorption at 325 GHz, we shift center frequencies of spws 1, 3, and 4 from the target lines. It allows us to cover multiple transtions within same spws.
The expected flux densities are calculated as described in the Science Case pdf file. Flux densities of continuum emission are derived based on the spectral energy distribution of f^1.8, where f is observed frequency, derived from previous observations (Hirota et al. in preparation, Plambeck et al. 2013 and references therein). Brightness temperature of the vibrationally excited H2O lines are calculated assuming a LTE condition of 3000 K as estimated from our cycle 0 observation of the 336 GHz line. The expected flux densities converted from these brightness temperatures are shown in Figure 3 and Table 1 in the Science Case pdf file. The selected lines are checked not to overlap the strong atmospheric absorption as shown in Figure 3. We request to achieve signal-to-noise ratio of 30 for the 336 GHz line in order to make images of high velocity components with less flux densities. Even if the excitation temperature are lower than expected, e.g. 1500 K, the 336 GHz line can be detected with signal-to-noise ratio of almost the same, ~30. The on-source time is calculated to be 4.51 minutes according to the output of OT. For the 323 GHz line which is close to the strong atmospheric absorption at 325 GHz, the signal-to-noise ratio will be about 10 under the best weather condition.
Such a high sensitivity and high spatial resolution observation would request unrealistically long observing time for other arrays. IRAM PdBI and SMA cannot achieve requested spatial resolution of <0.2" (e.g. 0.25" and 0.3" with PdBI and SMA, respectively), and CARMA cannot cover the 300 GHz band. Therefore, ALMA is indispensable for our proposed science goals.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose high resolution multi-transition observations of vibrationally excited H2O lines in a circumstellar disk around a massive YSO Source I in Orion KL.
In ALMA cycle 0, we detected a vibrationally excited thermal H2O line at 336 GHz (excitation energy of 2939 K) for the first time in Source I. The velocity centroid map of the 336 GHz line is elongated with a size of 0.2". Most importantly, it shows a clear velocity gradient perpendicular to a bipolar outflow, implying a rotating ring-like structure with an enclosed mass of 7 Solar masses. The spectral profile can be reconciled with an excitation temperature of >3000 K possibly heated via accretion. However, due to the limited resolution (0.4"), derived parameters would contain large uncertainties. Moreover, the temperature of the H2O gas could not be obtained by excitation analysis due to a lack of multi-transition data.
Vibrationally excited thermal H2O lines can be unique tracers to reveal the hot molecular disk around Source I. Our observations will allow us to derive its detailed properties such as size, mass, temperature, density, and H2O abundance, which are crucial to understand accretion processes in the disk.
